title: Have you ever had someone reach out to you about your writing and tell you that you changed their life? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve had several cases like that. Sometimes they say that what I wrote “helped them.”A few have said that it saved their lives.A couple have said that it helped, and they appreciated it, but it probably won’t be enough.A couple more have appreciated it and said (definitely) that it won’t be enough.The question doesn’t ask me how I feel about the feedback I’ve gotten, but I only answered the question that was asked, so that I could then say a little about how I feel about it. I won’t know if I am even willing to do that, until after I have either submitted this, or deleted it. First, let me be CRYSTAL CLEAR in saying that this is not about me being some awesome writer. I’m not. I am mediocre and wordy, but occasionally something clicks, and I write something beautiful. I’m okay with that. The few beautiful things I’ve written have sometimes been noticed and admired by a few people, and that feels wonderful. I see beauty everywhere, hiding in the ugliness, and I feel despair at the fact that I am utterly unable to articulate most of it. Nevertheless, I really am okay with it because the beautiful, terrible things wear me out, and my mediocre writing ability is kind of protective in that sense. The feedback that I listed above all comes from the same three answers. None of those answers feel “beautiful” to me, and they don’t reach people because they are beautiful; they reach people because they are written for people who are experiencing something that I have experienced. I get it. I’ve been there. I guess I’ll just make another list. When people tell me I “helped them”, feel happy and I usually cry.The first time someone said that I “saved their life”, I felt a species of joy that is beyond description, and I broke down and sobbed so hard that I could barely breathe. Then the other shoe dropped, and I realized that my “help” might very well have been a temporary thing, and that I will almost certainly never know either way. That made me cry a little more, but mostly it just made me hurt.The ones that have said that I “helped them, but not enough”, or “probably not enough” actually have been the easiest to bear. It feels good to know I helped someone. I wish that I had helped them more—that it had been “enough”—but I didn’t. It is a finite thing.A handful of people have failed to understand what my answers were actually trying to do. They have said nasty things to me, and that didn’t feel good, but I get it.One person told me that I had pushed her the other way and she had decided to end her life. I stared at my screen in shock, and a species of horror that is beyond description began to crawl up into my throat from the pit of my stomach; I got dizzy and I’m pretty sure that I came close to passing out. But she had thoughtfully added a line, below several blank lines, that said “j/k I love my life.” The relief that smashed into me when I saw that actually made my vision blotchy—I am sure that I nearly passed out. Instead, I began “sobbing” in a way that . . . well, it was something else, and I hope to God that I never, ever do that again. (I should add here that I really don’t blame her; I’m sure that she would never have done that if she had realized what was going on.)Those three answers haunt me every day. I have, several times, considered deleting them. I’ve been very fortunate to have had a few friends on Quora, and a wife, and a psychiatrist who have all assured me, and repeatedly made the case that “it’s okay;” it’s a “net positive”, etc. If you read this far, then I hope you will read the next thing, and take it to heart, because it is the only reason that I forced myself to write this answer, and it is important enough to be worth it. Every single day, huge gaping holes are torn from people’s lives because we are all walking on a high wire over a yawning canyon, without a net. It doesn’t matter what kind of writer you are, or aren’t. The things that you say, and write will affect people, whether they tell you about it or not. Eloquence and cleverness are all well and good, but they are nothing compared to the truly powerful thing. Kindness.

Before the existence of Quora I used to write in lined notebooks. I’d write about things I learned that made my life easier or made me suffer less, so I wouldn’t forget them. Then I’d take the notebooks and place them in a drawer. When I discovered Quora what I found was thousands of questions that echoed my own. “I’ve wondered this very thing” I’d think. “And the answer I found was helpful. Maybe others will find it helpful too.” I began sharing the things I’d discovered, and the most frequent comments back were “this is so helpful. Thank you.” I don’t have the power to change anyone’s life (other than my own.) But it makes me happy to know that people have found their own way and that reading what I write has pointed them to the only person who has the answers: themselves.

Yes, actually. Apparently I convinced someone here on Quora to get help and not commit suicide. I feel I can say this, because he wrote it publicly. I was shocked. I remember thinking, at the time, that it was probably just someone screwing around. I decided to answer anyway, just in case. I’m thankful that I did. I have had people contact me due to things I have written professionally to let me know what I wrote was very important to them. I wrote a book for lawyers on websites, and also, I write a lot as part of my lecturing. Not infrequently I hear from my colleagues about both my writing and my lecturing. I am always honored to hear from them.

Yes! I don’t like it. It makes me nervous. About a dozen people over my two years on Quora have messaged me to say they’ve changed something about their life because of something I wrote. That’s a lot of pressure. What if it doesn’t go well for them? I’m glad that people like what I write. I wish they wouldn’t change anything about their life because of it.

Yes. It is always an emotional experience for me, rewarding and humbling. One of the things that allowed me to leave my prior profession and begin my company seven years ago was feedback from people who told me I had written or said something that changed their life. Some of them are full of emotion and others are matter of fact, “I wanted you to know. . . “ messages. To me, the feedback that lets me know spending time here helps people I may never meet and whose lives I would have never touched in another way, feeds my soul and keeps me coming back.

Thanks Jon for a2a. Interesting questions make me smile; I am smiling. I have been trying to recall if someone ever said that but I think I do not enjoy that popularity, although, frankly I had always been a good writer since my early teens. I remember my teachers appreciating and encouraging me. I HAVE NOT LOST HOPE; I AM WAITING FOR SOMEONE TO BREAK THE BARRIER AND TELL ME THAT “YOU CHANGED MY LIFE THROUGH YOUR BRILLIANT WRITING”. But I want the person to be genuinely appreciating.
